docs.lead_paragraph: A nonprofit health maintenance organization sponsored by the eight Roman Catholic dioceses of New York State announced yesterday its purchase of a much larger, for-profit H.M.O., almost tripling the number of indigent patients it serves. Both H.M.O.'s exclusively serve Medicaid patients.

headline.main: Catholic H.M.O. Is Buying a Larger For-Profit Organization

docs.abstract: Fidelis Care New York, nonprofit health maintenance organization sponsored by eight Roman Catholic dioceses of New York State, acquires Better Health Plan, much larger, for-profit HMO, for $7.75 million; both HMO's exclusively serve Medicaid patients; Better Health was subsidiary of financially troubled Coastal Physician Group (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Jerry Roemer was supposed to be the new face of AIDS. For a few fleeting, joyful months last winter, Mr. Roemer was strong and vital. Though he had been infected with H.I.V. for years, the amount of deadly virus in his blood had plunged by 98 percent, the result of a powerful cocktail of new drugs called protease inhibitors that brought him back from the brink of death.

headline.main: Despite New AIDS Drugs, Many Still Lose the Battle

docs.abstract: Left Behind: When AIDS Drugs Fail, first in series of articles on protease inhibitors, powerful new class of drugs that revolutionized treatment of the disease; 18 months after protease inhibitors came into widespread use in United States, medications seem to be failing 25 percent to 30 percent of 150,000 people who are using them; Dr Anthony Fauci, AIDS expert, notes that people do well for six months or year, then HIV virus starts to come back; he estimates that failure rate of new drugs may be as high as 50 percent as result of these 'viral breakthroughs'; even so, Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced in June that AIDS deaths dropped 19 percent from last year; article details decade-long battle with HIV of one patient, and his devastating experience with protease inhibitors; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki signed into law a highly contested bill today that for the first time requires health insurance companies to pay for most services provided by chiropractors. The legislation is expected to bring new business to chiropractors and confers a new degree of credibility on a profession that has often been viewed with skepticism by members of the medical establishment.

headline.main: New Law Says Health Insurers Must Pay for Chiropractic Care

docs.abstract: Gov George E Pataki signs controversial bill that for first time requires health insurance companies to pay for most services provided by chiropractors (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Market Volatility Continues With 127-Point Fall in Dow The Dow industrials again moved by 100 points, but for the first time this week, the direction was downward.
docs.snippet: Market Volatility Continues With 127-Point Fall in Dow   The Dow industrials again moved by 100 points, but for the first time this week, the direction was downward.

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that open positions of short sales declined slightly in the most recent period, falling to about 3.36 billion shares for the month ended Aug. 15. The short interest, which represents shares borrowed and sold but not yet bought back by the seller, was equal to 1.7 percent of the total shares listed on the Big Board. On the smaller American Stock Exchange, a short-interest record was set for the seventh consecutive month, rising 2.7 percent, to 177.12 million shares for the period.

headline.main: Uncovered Short Sales Fall a Bit on the Big Board

docs.abstract: New York Stock Exchange says open positions of short sales declined slightly in most recent period, falling to about 3.36 billion shares for month ended Aug 15; short interest was equal to 1.7 percent of total shares listed on Big Board; short-interest record was set on American Stock Exchange for seventh consecutive month, rising 2.7 percent, to 177.12 million shares for the period; tables (L)
